user_request: A poem about a bird that comes down the walk and doesn't know the speaker is watching.

revision_history.draft:
The hallway stretches past the door
that leads to nothing, and the switch
has been on all week for no one.
I have memorized the dust-crawl
across the baseboard near the window,
how it thins where light touches.

There is a glass in the hall closet
with water in it since March.
The bird has stood behind it once,
just outside my seeing, and I noticed
because something wet left its print

on the cabinet wood — a footprint
smaller than a child's pinky, dark
as a smudge on a lens. I held the glass
to the wall between us until
the hall widened into the room

where the curtains pool against the chair.
A book open to pages no one turns
has gathered its own small history —
dust lines along the dog-ears,
a thumbprint I can't place.

I set the glass down. The water
holds what it always holds: the oval
of a ceiling, and somewhere in that circle
a fly has been buzzing since Tuesday.
The bird stood very still behind it

the way you hold still against a wall
when something is happening outside your body —
a window I can't quite reach,
say, or the faucet where water pools
then vanishes before you touch.

I went to the window. The yard was bare.
A cardigan on the hook had gone pink
in direct sunlight. I adjusted it.
The bird had moved closer to the glass.
We were both studying the same nothing —

the ceiling, the fly, the dust
that settles and is named for no one,
the quiet that fills a hallway
when every surface agrees
to keep its mouth shut.

Then the curtains stirred.

Not wind. Not anything so clean.
Something in the house decided
to test the windows, and the curtains —
which had hung there doing nothing
since October — went first,

and I heard the bird turn
inside its skull, like a stone
rolling off a table and stopping
at some smaller ledge where light can't reach,
and we both stood with our faces

pressed to that shifting cloth.
The curtain divided us
the way a door divides a room
into before-you-know-and-after.
I watched the dust motes

dance along the seam
where curtains meet wall. The bird
was still. It could have been
a branch, a question I had asked
myself by mouth and swallowed.

Then the light shifted again —
not brightness but direction,
the way a lantern tilts on its stand
and suddenly everything is facing somewhere else —
and the bird stepped through

what I only recognized
as an opening in the wall.
The curtain closed. The hall went dark
beneath the water in the glass.
I stood where I was, holding
still like the pages of that book,

each one pressed against its neighbor,
the dog-ears folded down as if
to keep a secret no one asks for.
Somewhere in the house the testing stopped.
The curtains stayed.

The dust motes settled on the carpet
where the bird had been. I couldn't see them.
I looked at the glass and saw only
the ordinary ceiling, the ordinary fly,
and understood that what I was watching

was not a bird. It was
a shape the water made
to hold still while everything else
went somewhere I would have to find
the door again, open it,

and go through alone.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — that the speaker and bird are both trapped inside their own awareness, neither aware of being watched until a shared moment forces recognition — is genuinely well-conceived. The poem earns this through meticulous domestic detail rather than announcing it. "I set the glass down. The water / holds what it always holds: the oval / of a ceiling" — that line break after "down" creates a small, felt pause where the speaker's body registers before consciousness catches up.

The closing sequence (curtains close, hall goes dark beneath water in glass) lands with real weight because it arrives through accumulated stillness rather than declaration. The final image — "I looked at the glass and saw only / the ordinary ceiling, the ordinary fly" — earns its ordinariness precisely because everything preceding it has been so specific.

The structural move from hallway to room to window back to hallway creates a genuine circuit of perception that mirrors the poem's theme.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / emotional overexplanation (lines 59–64):**
> "Then the curtains stirred.
> Not wind. Not anything so clean."
> — *Something in the house decided
> to test the windows, and the curtains —*
> 
> *which had hung there doing nothing
> since October — went first.*
> 
> *and I heard the bird turn
> inside its skull, like a stone
> rolling off a table and stopping
> at some smaller ledge where light can't reach,
> and we both stood with our faces*
> 
> *pressed to that shifting cloth.
> The curtain divided us
> the way a door divides a room
> into before-you-know-and-after.*

The bird "turning inside its skull" — this is the poem's one metaphor that reaches for easy feeling ("like a stone rolling off a table") and then retreats. "A smaller ledge where light can't reach" is vague enough to be decorative, not observed. The extended door-as-division-of-the-room conceit in lines 61–64 explains what the curtain already did: it created a boundary between two spaces of awareness. This explanation weakens the image's power.

**Direction:** Cut or radically compress these explanatory lines. Let the curtain do its work silently, then move into the next moment — the bird stepping through. Trust the reader and trust the image.

---

The poem is strong in its domestic specificity, its attention to what light does on surfaces, its refusal of grand declaration. The final turn works because it stays quiet. The revision direction is: tighten the ending by removing explanatory paraphrase; let images carry the emotional weight.

revision_history.draft:
The hallway stretches past the door
that leads to nothing, and the switch
has been on all week for no one.
I have memorized the dust-crawl
across the baseboard near the window,
how it thins where light touches.

There is a glass in the hall closet
with water in it since March.
The water held a date — April 13th,
the ring of a calcium line
where the cardigan had sat too long.

I have stood behind that glass
and read my own face backward
in its ripple. The bird has stood
behind it once, just outside my seeing,
and I noticed because something wet

left its print on the cabinet wood —
a footprint smaller than a child's pinky,
dark as a smudge on a lens.
I held the glass to the wall between us
until the hall widened into the room

where the curtains pool against the chair.
A book open to pages no one turns
has gathered its own small history:
dust lines along the dog-ears, a stain
that looks like water from a pencil tip,

and I suspect it's mine. I set the glass down.

The hallway was still. The dust motes
danced along the seam where curtains meet wall.
The bird was still. It could have been

a branch, a question I had asked myself
by mouth and swallowed. Then the light shifted —
not brightness but direction,
the way a lantern tilts on its stand
and suddenly everything is facing somewhere else —

and the bird stepped through
what I only recognized as an opening in the wall.

The curtain closed. The hall went dark
beneath the water in the glass.
I stood where I was, holding still
like the pages of that book,
each one pressed against its neighbor,

the dog-ears folded down as if
to keep a secret no one asks for.
Somewhere in the house the testing stopped.
The curtains stayed.

I looked at the glass and saw only
the ordinary ceiling, the ordinary fly,
and understood that what I was watching

was not a bird. It was
a shape the water made
to hold still while everything else
went somewhere I would have to find
the door again, open it,

and go through alone.

The hallway stretches past the door

A book open to pages no one turns

I looked at the glass and saw only
